admin_insights.admin_abbys_insight: Martin Melody has not yet worked on industry scale technology. Martin has experience in Java and Python. Martin is a passive learner.

discussion.content: Hi there üëã
<new>It‚Äôs Abby. I‚Äôm helping the SPR team
<new>connect with software engineers experienced in Java
<new> Ready for a few quick questions? <prompt button='I am Ready' value='ready'>
<chat_action display="I am Ready" value="ready">
Let's get started...
<new> I'd like to learn more a little more about your background.
The SPR team works on scalable enterprise systems that solve real world problems
<new>What is the biggest software project you‚Äôve worked on? In terms of complexity?
<new> Or active usage?

In terms of complexity, I would have to say the Reimbursement Site I've recently completed as a training project. It had over a dozen Java files, nearly a dozen HTML pages, and several AJAX methods, along with a simple SQL database. It implemented front-end pages using HTML, JavaScript, and most notably AJAX calls to tie it with the rest of the program. It passed or requested any info to/from one of two servlets, one to update the SQL database and one to retrieve a query result. Both pass the info to a single request helper, which redirected the calls to an appropriate controller. These controllers called DAO methods that accessed the database and retrieved/altered the data as need be. The database consisted of two tables, one sequence, and one procedure to add new values to the second table.
Awesome. Good to know
I'd like to learn about a recent project you handled from A to Z
<new> What type of project was it? Walk me through your process...

As I've said, my most recent project was the reimbursement site. I took a good look at the requirements, and reviewed samples of servlets, front controllers, and AJAX calls to figure out how to get HTML, Java, SQL and JavaScript all working together. Then I wrote out a good chunk of the code before testing it (admittedly not my best idea), and when I did test it, it didn't even login properly. I debugged by tracing the error to the request helper, where I found that the URI was not set up right, so I fixed that. Then I found a problem with a retrieval method, which I traced to a typo in an AJAX call. And I kept developing and debugging until I got the site to work properly. Then I gave a short demonstration as to how it worked.
Interesting
What new did you learn in the process?
<new> Any new skills or tech?

I've learned about how to use servlets and AJAX calls to get databases and websites working together, and how to connect to databases from Java. I've also learned that JavaScript can be too lenient for the programmer's own good.
Thanks for sharing
I‚Äôm getting a better feel for your experience.

<new> One last experience question... what programming language do you use most frequently other than Java? <prompt button='Python' value='python'> <prompt button='.NET' value='net'> <prompt button='Javascript' value='javascript'> <prompt button='Other' value='other'>
<chat_action display="Python" value="python">
That‚Äôs awesome. What do you like about Python?

I like that python is relatively simple, but also highly versatile. I also like the dictionary collection type, as i find that the key-value pairings make organizing and retrieving data much simpler (I've got to explore this advantage in detail in an Information Retrieval course I took in Spring).
Gotcha
Let‚Äôs move on with a few questions about your ideal role...
What‚Äôs the most important thing you‚Äôre looking for in a new opportunity?
Mostly I'm just happy to have an opportunity to learn more about software development and gain more experience that will help me in the industry.
Are there any new languages or tech you'd like to learn? Anything you want to be more hands on with?

I admit that I am unfamiliar with .Net programs, which I've seen come up on a few job postings, so I feel that it's something I could use. I also would like to learn more about Angular, which I've only touched upon.
That's helpful‚Ä¶
Ongoing learning is important at SPR, but also time consuming :-)
<new> How do you find the time or motivation to acquire new knowledge?

I feel that it helps when I have some sort of deadline to meet. Say I have a project that requires me to use knowledge I don't have, so I'll try to find examples of that knowledge in action, in pieces if I must, and work from that to get my program working.
Good approach, thanks for sharing
Ok, last question here‚Ä¶
<new>Can you tell me about your ideal stack?
<new> We work on a variety of projects, but most include build tools like Maven and cloud services like AWS. I want to understand how you think about picking the right tool for the job...
I admit to being relatively new to full stack, so Maven, AWS, TomCat and Git are all that I'm really familiar with.
Got it, thanks
Ok. I have a few logistics questions and we will be done
Do you need sponsorship to be able to work in the U.S., either now or at any time in the future?
<new> Just a Yes or No.
No
Ok
Our offices are in Chicago, IL
<new>Can you work from the office at least 4 days per week?
<new> Just Yes or No is fine
Yes
great, thanks
Last question, do you have a LinkedIn or Github Profile?
<new> Just paste a URL or username and I‚Äôll check it out.
www.linkedin.com/in/martin-melody     https://github.com/mmelody588
Thanks for your time today!
<new>We're reviewing applicants quickly
<new>I'll send you a follow-up email with timeline and expectations.
<new> You can respond there with any questions.

From the beginning, you were only primarily concerned with the people in the chat, them being unique to an array of different javascript users and being contained in their own chat room. Once the functionality was figured out there via different mocha tests, an HTML page was set up to keep track of user logs and to keep it contained within the individual chats. In a lot of ways, Javascript and the accompanying technologies are very open-ended to use, but it all seems very portable to since it can function for both personal and enterprise projects

Interesting
What new did you learn in the process?
<new> Any new skills or tech?

I learned a lot about prototyping software, and how it differs from other types of design software, as well as typical programming languages or IDEs. Beyond learning the ways in which a design should be both indicative of a purpose and functional to meet that end, I also learned a lot about working on a team where there are multiple types of tasks that need to be divided up. Prior experiences with teams were moreso about 4 people solving the same task together, as opposed to multiple people solving individual tasks to bring one larger project to life.

For this project I had to work with brain images which were in 3D and hence difficult to visualize. The segmentation was done using a deep learning architecture called U-Net. U-Net had previously only been used for segmentation of 2d images. And other architectures used for 3d image segmentation only gave little accuracy. <new>What is the biggest software project you‚Äôve worked on? In terms of complexity?
<new> Or active usage?

This biggest software I've had the honor of helping out with is the Qooley apps. Qooley is a small startup working on mobile travel apps that will be later launched on ios and andriod . Besides my software development internship at Qooley, most of my software engineering experience comes from my many projects done in my time at Turing school of Software & Design. There I dove deep in various web technologies, Object-Oriented Programming, Ruby, Ruby on Rails, RSpec, Sinatra, SQL, Active Record, HTML, CSS and of course Git and GitHub. I learned to work collaboratively with my team remotely via Slack and in person in different pairing styles like driver-navigator and ping-pong.
Awesome. Good to know
I'd like to learn about a recent project you handled from A to Z
<new> What type of project was it? Walk me through your process...

The recent project I worked on from beginning to end was BayCycles. BayCycles is a Ruby on Rails web app that utilizes ActiveRecord to parse through SF Bay Area Bike Share data. In this project, a station has many trips and trips have many weather conditions. Upon signing up, a user can view data analytics. Each station, trip, and condition page has a built-in form where a user can create their own. Additionally, we built an online commerce platform that allows for users to purchase items. A visitor can locate the store by clicking the link the bike share header.
Interesting
What new did you learn in the process?
<new> Any new skills or tech?

I learned to utilize ActiveRecord methods to efficiently query, calculate and report on information in the database. I learned about gems like Paperclip for our images and Rspec formatting gems to make test-driven development more fun and easier to read.

discussion.content: Hi there üëã
<new>It‚Äôs Abby. I‚Äôm helping the SPR team

<new>What is the biggest software project you‚Äôve worked on? In terms of complexity?
<new> Or active usage?
Currently I'm working with Verizon Telematics which is an IoT platform with more than 100 thousand active users.
Awesome. Good to know
I'd like to learn about a recent project you handled from A to Z
<new> What type of project was it? Walk me through your process...

Verizon Telematics is an innovative fleet management software that uses advanced fleet tracking techniques to seamlessly monitor your vehicle. It provides frequent health status updates, emergency services, entertainment etc., using a single cohesive system. It's completely an IoT platform where we are handling huge amount of customer data feeds in real time. We have constructed an ETL pipeline which consumes the data from the IoT sensors and streamline through Kafka with a data retention period of 7 days. The streamlined data is sent to Spark which acts as an analytics engine processing large scale data and storing it in different end points. Both history and real time data feeds are stored in different end points. We have a REST api to service requests for different business logic. The api hits the database to fetch the data requested by a business service to showcase it to the end user using Grafana Dashboard on the web application.
Interesting
What new did you learn in the process?
<new> Any new skills or tech?

I've used frameworks like Spring, Hibernate to build the REST api to serve the incoming requests. I've learned and implemented the docker containers for handling the micro-service architecture. I've got a chance to learn and implement the Kafka cluster for data streaming.

<new>Tell me about the last team you lead.
<new> What milestones did you hit? What were you most proud of?

Leading with education and a positive approach is my management philosophy. Knowing the 'why', and creating a route from that starting point has been a great lesson. With customer support teams, there can be times when the energy may become dull due to the nature of the department- complaints, concerns, etc. Taking time to see the positives, and recognizing teammates does a lot to boost morale. While managing the customer advocacy team at Vital, it was high stress as the company was scaling so fast. End of day check-ins worked well to hear everyone's grievances, and start the next day on positive footing. A milestone would be gaining placement in large national retailers like Anthropologie and Nordstrom. Leading a team that helped put a tasting menu presentation together took a great deal of planning in terms of logistics and education. By delegating tasks and trusting my teams ability we were able to be successful.
great

<new>What is your approach to managing customer health?
<new> Key metrics, growth levers, strategies, etc.

Organization is key! Calendars and spreadsheets are essential to not only keep track, but schedule follow-ups. Two week post purchase check-ins are an appreciated KPI. Checking in with a customer to see how they are enjoying the product, how it is selling, if they have questions,etc. showcases your caring approach to the relationship and instills trust. General account management principles of: increase current usage, stimulate new users, reduce customer churn provide great guidance at a high level. Monthly and Annual recurring revenue metrics are essential when considering retention from a monetary standpoint as well.

I appreciate working with a collaborative workforce where no idea is too big or small, but all about the perspective. discussion.content: Hi there üëã
<new>It‚Äôs Abby. I‚Äôm helping the Sprout Social team

Ok!
Thanks for sharing
A little more detail...have you worked in marketing technology?
<new> Just 'yes' or 'no' is fine.

My entire career has been in customer service, in one way or another. I spent about 6 years working in Hospitality with a majority of that time spent with Marriott. I grew a very solid foundation of customer service skills working for this company and have continued to utilize that training throughout my career. After working in the hospitality industry, I completely pivoted to a tech startup where I was an Account Consultant, helping service customers and their web based businesses. After spending a couple of years there, I did leave the company because there were no growth opportunities at the time. I ended up getting a teaching position in China and uprooted myself for a year of teaching and travel throughout Asia. When I came back, I jumped right into the tech start up scene again with a position at Belly Card where I was a part of the 7-11 team. I had my hand in a lot of different projects and support aspects there before I was laid off. Following that I was at another start up in the commercial cleaning industry as an Account Manager as well as Operations Manager. And now to my current role at Snapsheet where I have been for almost 2 years. I'm currently a Customer Success Manager for our Inbound call team, as well as manage 4 of our other managers.
Please give me a 'Yes' or 'No' response.
No. I do not have direct experience with marketing technology.
Please give me a 'Yes' or 'No' response.
No
No problem.
<new> What industries or products have you worked with in the past?

I started my career in the Hotel industry. When I moved into tech it was with SingleHop, which sells servers. At Belly Card we sold a tech platform for digital loyalty. At OfficeLuv we had a tech solution for office supply replenishment and cleaning services. At SnapSheet we have a tech platform to expedite the claims process for auto accidents.

Moving on to tools:
<new>Like many organizations, Sprout powers customer success with a CRM. Clean data is essential to sales, marketing, and customer success.

<new> What CRM are you most experienced with? <prompt button='Salesforce' value='salesforce'> <prompt button='Hubspot' value='hubspot'> <prompt button='Microsoft Dynamics' value='microsoft_dynamics'> <prompt button='Other' value='other'>
<chat_action display="Salesforce" value="salesforce">
Cool. What do you like best about Salesforce?

The ease of being able to house all of a clients information in one spot, including email communications, appointment dates, and services they are subscribed to. It's a great one-stop-shop for their data.
I'd like to learn about your leadership and coaching experience
<new>Tell me about the last team you lead.
<new> What milestones did you hit? What were you most proud of?

I am very proud of the team I'm currently coaching. It's a team of 15 individuals who service our incoming call volume to the company. It can be a high stress position due to the volume of calls we service, and not knowing the nature of what that inbound call is going to entail. I had the opportunity of launching our very first inbound team last summer, and am incredibly proud to be able to look back and see where we are today because going in we didn't know what to expect. It took a lot of trial and error to understand how we needed to service our customers, how many agents we needed staffed, and what specific phone Q's we needed to add. Those that helped in it's launch knew going in that it was going to be kind of crazy, but we knew that together we'd get through it. And we did. Today we have built out better processes surrounding what our Inbound team looks like and the service that we give to our customers. We have the highest QA scores amongst the rest of the organization, and that is something that I take great pride in. That I am able to give them the support that they need to be successful, and that I can coach to our quality standards.
great
Last experience question...you know retention is key in SaaS companies.
<new>What is your approach to managing customer health?
<new> Key metrics, growth levers, strategies, etc.

I liken customer retention to employee retention. Even your top performers need to have the same touch points as your low performers, because once you get comfortable and think they're solid with where there at, that's when the problems start. It's important to make sure that metrics are in place for each account, growth milestones, and to have proper communication cadence in place to stay ahead of the ball. I think it's important for a customer to feel like you are their go-to person, and that they can trust you. At the end of the day, we are all humans, and making that human connection with a client is going to do wonders for the overall health of the account.
Got it, thanks for sharing.
I‚Äôm getting a better picture of your experience...
<new> Let‚Äôs move on to what you want from a new role‚Ä¶
What‚Äôs the most important thing you‚Äôre looking for in your next opportunity?

The most important thing is having tools in place to be able to do my job well. One of the most challenging things that I currently go through is not having those tools, and trying to make the best out of what I do. For example, there are a lot of inconsistencies with data which makes it difficult for us to be able to forecast accurately for business needs. Oftentimes when going through employee reviews, the tools we have to support their performance is lacking. Additionally, clear growth and variety in work is very important to me. I want to be with a company for a long time and be able to progress - not just into different roles, but have exposure to more challenging work.
I see, good to know
I have a few more logistics questions and then we can wrap our convo.
Will you need a work visa or other work authorization to work in the U.S. now or at anytime in the future?
<new> Just 'yes' or 'no' is fine.
No
Our offices are in Chicago, IL but sometimes we work on-site with customers.

<new> Just 'Yes' or 'No' is fine
Yes
Last question, do you have a LinkedIn profile?
<new> Just paste a URL if you have one and I‚Äôll check it out.
https://www.linkedin.com/in/cara-mooney-77b62b27/
Ok, thanks
Thanks for your time today!
<new>We're reviewing applicants with the team over the next few weeks
<new>I'll send you a follow-up email with timeline and expectations.
<new> You can respond there with any questions.

i currently lead 2 cross-functional teams (5 client success managers, and 5 Field Service reps) that have worked together to hit our retention and sales metrics. great
Last experience question...you know retention is key in SaaS companies.
<new>What is your approach to managing customer health?
<new> Key metrics, growth levers, strategies, etc.

In order to retain clients, it's important to make sure that they are using and getting value out of the system.  I look at things like how many people are using the product at a given client, who sees the data, how often, how many different departments are seeing value - how deep are our roots.  It's important to track how they are using the system, are they using it at a very basic level, do they have all the bells and whistles, are they using the system in the way it was designed, are they engaging in feedback loops to constantly improve the product.  I also like to take into consideration things like contract growth, NPS, and satisfaction scores as well as client side parameters like POC turnover, executive turnover, and overall company health.  When any of these things change, there is a playbook for what happens to make sure that everything gets back in balance.
